item.description: It's learning fun the Golden way as children match color dominoes along a spiraling color path. Color recognition and matching skills are reinforced. For ages 3 and up.

Shuffle all the tiles and give 5 to each player. Place all the remaining tiles in the center face down. Players race to find letters that match their words and the player who finishes all of their words first is the winner. For ages 4 and up.

Tactic Blue is a compilation of 6 abstract games by 3 different authors. All of the games are played on a two-sided board, using the hex-grid or square-grid side.


 Accasta
 Abande
 Attangle
 Attraktion
 Alva
 International Checkers


Accasta, Abande, Attangle are games designed by Dieter Stein and are part of his stacking games trilogy. Attraktion, a game by Jaroslav Cichocki, uses pull force (attraction) in movement to form a winning condition. Alva, designed by Alvydas Jakeliunas, is like a souped-up version of checkers. The last game included is a classic International Checkers. Apparently the gameboard and components happened to be compatible. Some of the games were previously published on websites.

item.description:
Miniature wargame science fiction skirmish rules.

5150: What is it? - Extract from the rules:
5150 is a game of sci-fi skirmish warfare. The rules handle fast and furious firefights set in the far future. If all you want to do is play “one up” unrelated battles on the tabletop you can do just that. But if you want, 5150 can be more than just a wargame.

5150 thrusts you into a universe populated by both humans and aliens. Real aliens. Not just characters with a number changed here or there to make them "tougher" but real aliens that act differently.

5150 starts you off in the middle of the action. Choose whom you are and what you want to do. Star Army soldier commanding a military formation sound good? Maybe a mercenary making ends meet by salvaging equipment on far off planets? How about an adventurer, coming and going as you please always in search of that one big "find" that’ll make you famous? Heck, you can even be a blue-skinned alien if you choose! With 5150 you’re only limited by your imagination. If you can imagine it you can do it.

5150 provides a changing universe to campaign in. Not only your actions but also the actions of those beyond your control help shape your life. But like in real life first you must survive before you thrive as you try to establish yourself and your followers as a force to be reckoned with. Gain experience and skills as you successfully move through the galaxy. Find friends; make enemies, its all there in 5150. As time passes challenges change and it will take a combination of tactics and strategy to succeed. And a little luck won’t hurt either!

If you’ve played Chain Reaction 2.0, All Things Zombie, or Nuts! to name a few the mechanics in 5150 will be familiar but if you haven’t don’t worry. 5150 is a stand-alone game, easy to learn and fun to play.

From the Three Monkey Games website:www.monkeypoker1.com

Once again, the geniuses at Three Monkey Games have turned a classic game on its ear and came up with something BRAND NEW! Introducing MonkeyWinks! The popular indoor game that is easy to learn for kids, and formidable enough to appeal to adults wanting a special challenge.

Like its predecessor, MonkeyWinks is a game played with sets of small, thin discs (called winks) lying on a special felt mat. Players use a larger disc (called a squidger) to pop a smaller disc into flight by pressing down on one side of the smaller disc. The basic goal of an informal game (easily playable by young children) is to cause the smaller discs to land inside a pot or cup. The formal game has a more robust set of rules, goals, and strategies suitable to serious competition for adults and older children.

MonkeyWinks is interactive fun for all players, pros and beginners alike. However, MonkeyWinks is a lot more than just a flipping disc game. For example, the included "Go Bananas"™ cards incorporate random events and player changes inspired by everyday kids games. 
www.monkeypoker1.com

From Three Monkey Games website:www.monkeypoker1.com

Looking for a fun, new indoor game idea for children, and kids of all ages? Learn Poker along with Berry "The Bluffer" Bananahammock, "Fearless" Freddy Funkymunky, Albert "All In" Alexander and Mr. Bill "Bananas" Dole as they play this new and fun variation on the most popular card game in recent years: Texas Hold 'Em!

WHY MONKEY AROUND WITH A GOOD THING?!

MONKEY POKER™ takes the easy to learn card game Texas Hold 'em, and adds the entertaining randomness of such classic children's games as Monopoly™ and The Game of Life™. It's a great game idea for your next kid's party or sleepover!

The winner of each poker hand has to take a "Go Bananas!" card from a deck, and then do what the card says for bonus chi(m)ps! The tasks range from the silly ("Take $1000 in Chimps from everyone, except for the person with the hairiest feet!") to the sublime ("Switch seats with the person to your left. Now have the other monkeys do the same.").
The Chimps awarded by the "Go Bananas cards" can go either way, either to the winner or another player, so everyone has an equal chance of winning!

Plus with additional ways to win, MONKEY POKER™ is a hilariously fun card game with "a peel" for all ages! We guarantee you'll like it a bunch! www.monkeypoker1.com

name.value: Kragmortha: Der dunkle Turm des Meisters

item.description:
From the website of the publisher:

Oh clever goblins, will you be able to avoid the wrath of the Dark Lord (Rigor Mortis, the Master of all Evils) while he wanders in his study? Terrible spells will be cast upon those who are hit by the glances of the Dark Lord!

Kragmortha is a party game for 2-8 players that will be afflicted by exhilarating penances. No one will resist its humor!

BEWARE! This game produces physical penances and is nocive (definition of nocive is : Hurtful or injurious) to the health!

Kragmortha shares artwork with Aye, Dark Overlord! The Red Box

item.description:
Atlantaopoly is a game concerned with business trade in Atlanta. The object of the game is to accumulate as much wealth as possible through the purchase, trade, and development of businesses.

Board game spaces include Turner Broadcasting System, Friends of Zoo Atlanta, Atlanta History Center, The Carter Presidential Center, and Georgia-Pacific.

Players may improve their businesses by building high-rises (two, three, four, and five-story buildings) and eventually sky scapers.

name.value: You Gotta Be Kidding! The Crazy Game of "Would You Rather...?"

item.description: Children's version of the Zobmondo!! games (ages 7 and up). On your turn, you roll a die and move your pawn that many spaces. Pick up a "Would You Rather" card and select which of the two choices you would rather do (such as "Would you rather: 1) Run across a hungry alligator's back; or 2) Run under an angry elephant?"). Your opponents decide which they'd think you'd do as well, and record it by putting a token under their palm with either the "Choice 1" or "Choice 2" side facing up. Then you announce your choice, explain your choice, and try to guess which choice your opponents thought that you would make. Each time you guess correctly, you move your pawn one space on the board. The game ends when someone crosses the finish line.

In Harry Potter Championship Quidditch players take on the role of either Harry Potter or Draco Malfoy in a high-energy 1-on-1 version of author J.K. Rowling's magical sport. 
Each player must fire small red balls - quaffles - through rotating hoops in the center of the playing field. Each successful shot is worth ten points, but also more often than not gives the quaffle to your opponent. With eight quaffles flying back and forth, though, there's plenty to go around!
At a random point in the contest, the game will launch a gold ping-pong-esque ball - the Golden Snitch - into the air. Whichever player catches the ball is awarded 150 points, and the game ends.
The game, which runs on two C batteries, provides sound effects during the game and also keeps track of the score, which can get into the thousands.

"I game based on the ballad by Theodor Fontane. The garden is set up and the pears are distributed, depending on the number of players pears are put onto the tree, always at one side, or a player hands on pears to be put up. Pears must be taken with one Hand and always from the same side and be put onto a branch of the three. Depending on the variant one harvests pears that fall from the unused side and may keep them or give them away. The player with the most valuable pears after a preset number of rounds wins the game. Ballad printed in the rules.

Dexterity and tactical game * 2 or more players * no age given * Designer: Reinhold Wittig * Graphics: Karin und Reinhold Wittig * Edition Perlhuhn, Germany, 2005 *** Edition Perlhuhn * www.perlhuhn.de * webmaster@perlhuhn.de"

From www.spielen.at 2006/11/31

Finally the night has arrived! All the little witches can fly to witch mountain and participate in the big dance. However you have to watch out for the little thunder witch, because her broom is a bit slow and her wand keeps shooting thunder by accident.

There's a track of 7 spaces between the witch house and the mountain. You have five face down cards, with symbols on them in front of you.

On your turn you roll the die. If you get one of the five symbols, you get to flip over one card from each opponent. If you find a matching symbol, you get to advance a space towards the mountain. Then everyone flips their card back over. If you roll the ThUndER (BUMP bump Bahhhh...) Witch symbol you move your left most card to the right. (BUMP bump Bahhhh...) :D

item.description:
ElectraWoman & DynaGirl must reach the Secret Scientific Formula space in their ElectraCar and return to ElectraBase while using different combinations of Computer Power symbol cards to thwart the bad guys: The Sorcerer, The Pharaoh, The Empress of Evil, The Spider Lady, Glitter Rock, and Ali Baba.

Each Trouble Space depicts a different combination of Computer Power symbols needed in order to overcome it. Computer Powers include ElectraData, ElectraForce, ElectraBeam, and a few Super Power cards (a combination of all three). If a player does not have the right combination of Computer Powers for that particular Trouble Space, they must remain in it until the correct combination is achieved. A card is drawn every turn, regardless of whether a player can move.

Additional cards used to obstruct opposing players include ElectraPush and ElectraComp Blocked.

This game is based on the short-lived Sid and Marty Krofft live action children’s television series from 1976, starring Deidre Hall in her first major television role as ElectraWoman and Judy Strangis as DynaGirl.

Players seek to answer trivia regarding famous news stories dating back as early as 1900. Categories include: 20th Century, 21st Century, Sports, Arts & Entertainment, and Science & Technology.

Victory is achieved by scoring five of one category, a 3/2 combination, or a run including each category, so players are awarded both for breadth of knowledge as well as expertise.

Of particular interest to trivia buffs is that each question, when answered, includes the story behind the headline.

"The game of strategy, fun, and fascinating facts."

www.newshoundgame.com

April 1863
Union General Ulysses S. Grant embarks on another attempt to wrest control of the last major Confederate stronghold on the Mississippi River from the rebels; the fortress city of Vicksburg. Numerous other attempts have failed miserably. The ill-fated campaign from the north, short circuited by that devil Forrest's raid on Grant's supply lines. The jinxed canal, dug through the swamps in an attempt to bypass the city's guns. Now another plan is in motion. Grant will march his Army of the Tennessee through the Louisiana swamps, sneak his ships past the rebel fortress in a daring run of the gauntlet, conduct the largest amphibious invasion in U.S. history, separate himself from his supply base, wedge himself in between two rebel armies, and seize control of the city from the east! All the while battling politicians and public opinion as much as the Confederate armies. Somehow, his daring plan worked, and the Mississippi once again flowed unvexed to the sea.

But things could have been different. Find out how....

This operational level game uses the block unit system to re-create the limited intelligence of the actual campaign. Players maneuver their forces without adequate knowledge of their opponents strengths or even location. The game board spans the campaign topography, from the swamps of eastern Louisiana to the mountainous terrain around Jackson Mississippi. A point to point movement system is employed on a 20 x 24 playing map. Limited command abilities and critical supply wagons are key to managing your armies and achieving victory.

Kruzno is an abstract strategy game usually played with two players on a hexagonally tiled board. Though the rules are extremely simple (three minutes to learn for most players), the number of possible moves and interactions are comparable to chess.

Kruzno uses standard chess pieces (bishops, knights and rooks) but is more closely related to hexagonal checkers and R.C. Bell's Jungle Game. Like the Jungle Game, capturing is non-transitive: bishops capture knights; knights capture rooks; rooks capture bishops. This split between offense and defense means that most standard strategies of move and capture have to be scrapped or reworked.

Game variants include versions with reduced number of pieces for faster play and expansion sets for three players.

Home Page: http://www.kruzno.com/
Card driven movement game for children. Based on the "Peepul Pals" line of books and dolls published by Whitman in the 1960's

Played on a large (approx 4 foot x 4 foot) vinyl mat. Players try to blow plastic balls across another player's "loser line". You must try to prevent other player's ball from crossing your line or you earn 1 loser card. Be careful if you touch your ball you earn 2 loser cards.

The game ends when the 45 loser cards are given out. The player with the fewest cards wins.

item.description: Spin and move children's game. Featuring the cats Jean-Tom and Mewsette traveling through Paris.
Players race around the State Fair ground stopping at attractions to collect prizes. Be the first player to collect 6 different prizes and you win.
Spin and Move boat racing game.

Gulf War is a Malaysian board game from 1990, using as its theme the then ongoing war in the Persian gulf. Its game mechanism is borrowed from An Qi (literally dark chess, because pieces are covered at the start and so unknown to the players: it is a game played using Xiangqi pieces). Each side has a number of pieces ranking from President down to Hostages or Civilians, and also Bombs, Fighter Planes and Oil-fields. Like An Qi (and for that matter games like LuZhanJunQi and Stratego), the pieces have a ranked order and higher ranked pieces eliminate lower ranked ones. Pieces start face-down and are randomly distributed in alternate colors on the 6X6 square grid that is the game board. Players take turn to expose pieces and once exposed, pieces may be moved one space orthogonally. Enemy pieces are eliminated by a higher or equal ranked piece moving on to them. There are special rules for specific pieces - the Assassin may eliminate the President, Bombs neutralize (i.e. both pieces get eliminated) all other pieces, capturing an Oil-field/Hostages/Civilians piece allows substitution of your own piece for a previously eliminated piece, etc. The Fighter Plane has the capture of the Pao (Cannon) in An Qi - just like in Xiangqi, it jumps over another piece to land on a distal piece and capture it. 
The game is won by the player who is able to capture both the opposing President and Vice-president.

The game has interesting details - one player takes the Iraqi side and the other is the Allied side. The President, Vice-president and Ally pieces are different and have pictures appropriate to the side (Saddam, Bush, Gaddfi and Thatcher all feature). Another difference is that the Iraqis have a Civilians piece but the Allied forces has a Hostages piece instead (in the game, they are equivalent). The board comes with two sides - one side has yellow and blue circles to show where the pieces go. The other has the same 6X6 grid superimposed on a background map showing the Persian gulf.

Spin and move children's game. Based on the TV show Bozo the Clown. The board shows Bozo in the Circus,under the big top.

Climb the ladder, go across the high wire, if you fall there is a safety net, as you race to the finish line.

World Tank Campaigns (WTC) is a series of tactical games that employ cards, miniatures, and boards in a fast-playing action game designed primarly for solitaire, with one-on-one action as well. WTC is the brainchild of Dana Lombardy, designer of the award winning Streets of Stalingrad.

The game is card driven with dice used for combat and special actions. Combat is represented on a tactical to operational level.

World Tank Campaigns: Bulge: Germany’s last gamble in the Ardennes to change the course of the war initially surprised the American forces, but it resulted in a major Allied victory. Each player play the role of a German or American tank commander directing a platoon of tanks with supporting forces. The game plays out on a Battle Board unique to the scenario and tanks used in that scenario.

The World Tank Campaigns: Bulge Set has everything needed to play SOLITAIRE and 2-PLAYER games:


 2 historically accurate, incredibly detailed 1/144 scale plastic tanks
 Miniature tanks are pre-painted and fully assembled and include a historical information sheet about each tank
 2 full-color battle “boards” unique to the Ardennes and the Sherman M4A3 and Panther G tanks
 6 custom designed army-specic dice, plus standard d6 & d10
 88 full-color playing cards make gameplay fast and exciting
 55 die-cut play aid tokens (not show here), illustrated rulebook, and Quick Start Rules for the solitaire game


2 EXPANSION Sets include:


 22 additional cards, a Jagdpanzer IV tank-killer or King Tiger super heavy tank with their own unique battle boards and scenarios.


Home Page of the Game: http://www.world-tank-campaigns.com/
Home Page for the Miniatures: http://www.world-tank-museum.com/

link.value: World War 2: Battle of the Bulge

name.value: Yogi Bear: Go Fly a Kite Game

item.description: Spin and Move Children's game. Game Board featuring the animated characters of Yogi Bear, Boo-Boo Bear, Mr. Ranger, Quickdraw McGraw, Huckleberry Hound and others Flying kites.

Deduction game based on the ABC TV show "Arrest and Trial" starring Ben Gazzara and Chuck Conners.

Move around the city collecting clues and questioning witnesses.

It is the same board and mechanics as "Dragnet".

Players in Escalation! want to collect as few cards as possible. Each player starts with a hand of six cards from a deck that contains cards numbered 1-13, three jokers that can be worth 1-7, and two "pass" cards. One player opens by playing a single card or multiple cards with the same value, then calls out the sum of the cards played. The next player — and each player after that — must play cards to surpass that sum or else collect all of the cards played so far, after which they open with one or more cards. As soon as one player is out of cards, everyone else adds their cards in hand to the cards that they've collected and tallies their score.

After playing as many rounds as the number of players at the table, whoever has the lowest score wins!

item.description: Spin and Move children's game based on the animated TV show "The Flintstones".
Deduction game based on the ABC TV show "The Detectives" starring Robert Taylor. Players race around the board collecting clue's. A spinner determines the location of the various clues.

A football board game that is designed to be played while watching actual games on TV. Players place bets on the board indicating what play they think the offensive or defensive will make in the actual game.

In Hand 2 Hand, players take turns drawing various things while other players attempt to guess what's being drawn. Points are scored for correct guesses.

The trick is that partners must use the "double-handed drawing arm", working together to properly draw each subject.

Money Maker, A game of free enterprise. Is a very monopoly like game that is used to market local businesses. It consists of a gameboard, 2 dice, 4 pawns, a rules booklet, money in four denominations, a pad of Business Ownership and Expansion Record sheets, and a set of risk cards. Rather than using houses and such to show ownership and improvement (as monopoly does) Branches are noted on the sheets. On the gameboard all of the businesses are representations of local businesses.

Wormhole by Worldworks Games is a tabletop space combat game which promises an affordable yet paradigm shifting gaming experience. Taking the "virtual board game" concept to the bleeding edge; instead of forcing overpriced lead miniatures on players Wormhole offers a complete fleet of high quality 3-D models that you print and build from your home printer. This feature alone gives players the opportunity to build massive fleets without breaking the bank.

Wormhole promises "cinematic" space combat with visual style and presentation not yet seen in the genre. Rules are easy to understand but offer a scaling level of depth for a variety of play styles. Wormhole also introduces an interactive damage and orders system which removes heavy book-keeping tasks and replaces it with a "control panel-like" interface (you feel absolutely in control, barking orders to your fleet). A number of unique gaming elements conspire to make Wormhole a truly immersive and completely original gaming experience.

Home Page: http://www.worldworksgames.com/wormhole.html

item.description: Designed to easily control 15-20 capital ships a side (which can be 4-5 squadrons), while concentrating on squadron level tactics, Firepower Pass uses a unique command oriented system that allows units to attack as individual ships (i.e. at a tactical level) yet defend and maneuver in 3D as squadrons. Octagonal 3D movement tiles easily and elegantly depict the 2D vector of 3D movement.
This is a memory game where each player is trying to find and build the alphabet made of puzzle pieces of their chosen color.

name.value: Go Diego Go! Rescue the baby dinosaur

item.description:
A themed Chutes & Ladders variant with some additions, like Rescue Pack squares that allow an extra roll, hang glider squares that allow (and force) the player to switch positions with someone else. The board now goes to 91 and there's a dinosaur track on top.

Alternate cooperative rules are included with some interesting additional developments.

Includes board, rules, 6 pawns, 1 die, rubber dinosaur.

item.description: Board game based on Horse Show Jumping. The game has four plastic horses with riders, a variety of fences, walls and other items to make up the Show Jumping course on the board.

Hell & Uncivil Disorder is a set of miniature wargame rules for Brushfire Wars and "Magic" in the 20th Century (there is also a Science Fiction option because Jim Webster is "happily confident our descendants will be as incompetent as we are").
The rules are suitable for use with a variety of figure scales (including a 1/300 variant) with a ground scale of approximately 20 yards to the inch.
The rules are intended for conflicts where first world forces are fighting third world forces and hence treats technology as magic (as per the well know Arthur C Clarke quotation) but may be used for any modern conflict.

Imperial Commander is a set of miniature wargame rules for science fiction combat. It was based around the Tabletop Figures range of 15mm Sci Fi figures and was designed to give a fast game when using around 50 figures per side.
The rules cover light infantry through to power armor, force shields and vehicles. They also contain some army lists and conversions from Laserburn and Combat 3000.

Get ready to experience the Wichita Scene! Live and work at an exciting pace, make and break deals, buy and sell property, finance and liquidate businesses!

You'll get to establish proper connections with the planning director, influence the board of realtors, confront a Labor Leader and deal with the Downtown Revitalization Committee.

You may have thought Wichita doesn't have a scene... well, that may be true. But now, YOU can live the dream!

item.description: A game very much in the vein of Trivial Pursuit. Semantic requires players to answer questions based on the meaning of words. Players must complete a path around the board answering questions as they go. Movement is based on a dice roll.

This game from the Wing National Game Company of St. Augustine, FLA was indeed copyrighted in 1898.

[The box says this game was published by Parker Brothers.]

The game consists of a Battle Ground with 31 Navy Paths (31 circles) each of which are intersected at 5 or 6 places by other paths. These intersections are called fighting positions. Red, White and Blue designs across the battleground are called Line of Shot.

The game comes with 9 white and 9 black washers that represent Battleships from two Navies.

Each navy changes form (moves) in turn. Only one move is allowed at a time. The sinking of an opponents ship occurs when you manage to get two of your ships on the same line of shot as that of an enemy ship, with your nearest ship half way between the enemy and your back ship. When the range is so short that your two ships and the enemy lay in 3 consecutive positions then the enemy is captured and not sunk. When that happens you may remove the captured ship and place any of your ships in one of the starting positions. This allows you to fix placement errors by returning your ship to the start.

Free translation from back of the box:

Do you dream about becoming a successful show jumping star just like Malin Baryard? In Malin’s own game WORLD CUP you get to test your talent in exciting jumping competitions. Initially you compete on a borrowed horse and try to collect enough prices to get all necessary equipment and a horse of your own. With that accomplished you just have to win one final competition to become the World Cup champion. All you need is luck, a bit of tactics and some horse knowledge.

Event cards and trivia questions make the game full of action and lots of fun. You also get to ride different horses and the better you perform the better horses you get to ride. Many of the available horses are "celebrities" and if you are really good you might even get to jump Butterfly Flip!

Good luck!

Malin Baryard

It´s a little like the German game "Mau Maus".
There are four colors with five cards each. Also there are colored "law-cards"
You start with 12 coins and the game ends if one player has no more money at the end of a round. The player with the most money will win.
If it´s your turn you have to place a card on the start card. It has to match the color or the name of that card. If you can´t place a card you have to take a new one. If you can´t place it neither your turn ends.
The law-cards force other player to do silly things every turn or get a disadvantage during the round or at the end of it.
A few of the cards have instant effects on them.

box-inventory
82 cards
60 coins (gold and silver)
rules

After a very long night of fishing the boats replete with fish return to the port. In the Strap begins the auction of all the apprehensions, every player is interested in obtaining the highest price, and of all those more species better, spending the less amount of money.

A game of fishing auctions for from 3 to 6 players. It consists of 40 cards, 5 for each of the species and 90 coins.

A tactical dice-game for Hannover's places of interest, from Bothfield to Kirchrode.
"People Nature Technology" was the motto of the 2000 Hannover expo.


Ein taktisches Würfelspiel zu Hannoverschen Sehenswürdigkeiten von Bothfeld bis Kirchrode.
"Mensch Natur Technik" war das Motto der Expo 2000 in Hannover.

In Top Aktionär (Top Stockholder) the goal is to become the richest player in the defined play-time. To achieve this goal, players buy and sell stock. Whoever buys stock, gets shares and then must pay dividends. In the game,it is possible to purchase many stocks, and to unexpectedly be tossed out of control by other players.


Bei Top Aktionär geht es darum, nach Ablauf der festgesetzten Spielzeit der reichste Spieler zu sein.
Zu diesem Zweck kauft und verkauft man Aktien. Wer Aktien besitzt, erzielt Einnahmen und muss auch Dividenden zahlen.
Im Spiel geht es darum, möglichst viele Aktien zu erwerben, aber auch immer für unerwartete Ausgabengerüstet zu sein.

Be the king of Pot, Hash and 'Shrooms. You roll dice and progress around the board. In the process you 'make connections' wherein you can buy and sell illegal commodities. 
The Market Level for commodity prices will vary as the game goes on. Be the first to accumulate $20,000 and you win!

(from MMP website:)

On September 14th, 1862, the rebel division of D.H. Hill was surprised and attacked by Ambrose Burnside's Wing of the Army of the Potomac. Hill's men held out all day against a rising tide of Federal troops from both the 1st and 9th Corps and were saved only by the late arrival of D.R. Jones and Hood's divisions.

Despite the fact that it was a rather sharp defeat for the rebels, Hill remained justifiably proud of the fight his men managed for 12 long hours atop South Mountain. They had given Lee the time he needed to concentrate his army in the face of a suddenly aggressive Federal force.

South Mountain is the fourth game in the Civil War, Regimental Series. With one map and a manageable number of counters, it is the first game in the series to offer a full, intense, battle that is playable in an evening. And re-playability is very high, given the variable arrival of some key Rebel forces and the application of Confederate and Union Random Events.

Contents:

 1 22"x32" mapsheet (sneak peek)
 2 countersheets
 Civil War Brigade Series rules
 Regimental Subsystem rules
 South Mountain game specific rules
 2 Charts & Tables booklets
 Player Aid Card
 Two dice




Unit Scale: Regiments and Batteries
Hex Scale: 100 yards/hex
Players: 2 and up
Complexity: Medium


South Mountain creation team:
Designer: Dave Powell
Series Designer & artwork: Dean Essig
Development: Bob Cloyd

name.value: The Bee Safe or Bee Sorry Game

item.description:
The Bee Safe or Be Sorry Game helps kids be aware of dangers. It features "Stinger" and "Buzzie".

The age recommendation is 4 and up.

The players are represented by playing pieces which are shapes, a square, a circle, a triangle, and a rectangle. There are Honeycomb cards, Stinging Bee cards, Safety First cards, Buzzie Bee cards, Safehouse cards, Stranger Cards, and a spinner.

Players start with three Honeycomb cards and move about the board drawing the other cards. The other cards have situations on them that are to be read and then directions to either move (forwards or backwards) and/or draw/lose Honeycomb cards. The situations all have to do with safety.

Th winner is the first to reach the hive first or obtain 15 Honeycomb cards!

link.value: Tee Pee Toys, Jessup Paper Box Co.

item.description: This is a trivia game based on Yellowstone Park - the object to collect unique sets of park "treasures (which are cards of photos for example). Each trivia question has 3 level of difficulties.

This game is a very simple and typical roll and move game, where players try to go from the beginning to the track which has 100 positions. In places where there's a red position instead of a yellow, players encounter different kinds of problems which may affect who's the winner.

Paletti game no. 2893

In this game, the board is built of puzzle pieces at the beginning of the game. Each puzzle piece contains a question category. All the players use the same button, which is moved according to a die throw. The question is asked in the category of where the button gets to. There is also an extra category, which contains yes-no questions of all the categories.

This game seems to be a Finnish version of the game called "Geni!" (http://www.boardgamegeek.com/game/22289). This is written in the box cover too. However, there are some differences. For example, in the Finnish version there are 56 puzzle pieces instead of 15 in Geni!

item.description:
Kick-o-Mania is a dexterity soccer/football game played on a large 4x7 foot playing field. The figures are fully positionable and controlled by your actions.

Rules and a full range of figures and game accessories are available in stores or through the website http://www.kick-o-mania.com

[Publisher]
Great on the road, at home, and every place in between. Travel fun for the whole family. 
Play I Spy, Road Sign Challenge, and more with 54 colorful cards!

[Submitter]
A collection of simple kid games suitable for playing at travel. 
(1) ROAD SIGN DOMINOES - a domino game using road sign paired cards.
(2) ROAD SIGN CHALLENGE - Looking around outside the car for the road sign pictured on card.
(3)I SPY - Looking around to spy the letter (from the drawn card) on license plates, billboards, signs or anywhere else.
(4) I SPY, TOO! - Looking for things that begin with the pictured letter.
(5) ALPHABET TRAVELER - Name a place that begins with the pictured letter.
(6) I'M GOING ON A TRIP... - Make a word chain using words that start with the pictured letter(s), and alternately repeating the word chain plus a new word.

From the publisher:

An entirely new concept in the RPG-boardgame hybrid genre. A d20 based boardgame equally as usable as an occasional distraction or full fledged campaign.

Some features of the boardgame:

d20 ensures a familiar basis and a quality rules set 
32 page rule book containing 6 core races, 12 core classes, and 52 unique special abilities 
60 full color folding miniatures for your characters, usable for this boardgame or any other purpose 
A starter dungeon to get everything started, including full color maps and unique monsters with folding miniatures of their own
Beautiful illustrations by V. Shane, Sacrosanct Games, and Octavirate Entertainment

Game, Set & Match is a Tennis board game that uses a die and deck of cards for playing shots, and a board and pawn to show the position of the ball on court.
Players serve by rolling a die marked Ace/Let/In/Out, then if the ball is in play, cards are played for each shot of the rally that determine the stroke played and the position of the ball on the court. Singles or doubles can be played.

name.value: Flintlock: Black Powder, Cold Steel - Volume I: Carolina Rebels

item.description:
THIS GAME HAS BEEN DISCONTINUED.

Flintlock is a company-level American Revolution gaming at a scale of c.50 yards per hex and about 50 men per counter/unit. The system emphasizes the limits of command, training, and discipline, all in the milieu of the very linear style of warfare in the pre-Napoleonic era. In addition, it uses a most unusual set of mechanics for resolving shock combat. Will you have your troops go into close order, or spread out for better fire possibilities? What are the pros and cons of the rifle-armed American militia? Can your dragoon forces exert any influence?

Flintlock is designed for quick learning and easy play. Game rules are short, but they cover almost every aspect of battle at this micro level. Playing time is less than 2 hours.

The battles chosen highlight small unit tactics in the grueling Southern Campaign, where both sides had ample opportunities to watch, learn and practice, with an emphasis on Formation. Some of the great commanders of the war, from Nathanial Greene and Daniel Morgan to Lord Cornwallis and the infamous, but capable, Banastre Tarleton are in full action.

The Scenario/battles, all (well, most) with armies of one or two thousand men, include:


 Camden (17 August 1780) Lord Cornwallis stands and confronts a much larger force under Horatio Gates, but the rebel militia disintegrates and Gates’s army is routed in a major British victory. 



 Cowpens (17 January 1781) Daniel Morgan conducts a masterful, tactical battle, defeating Banastre Tarleton and destroying the dreaded British Legion in one of the major victories of the war.



 Guilford Courthouse (15 March 1781) Nathanial Greene outnumbers Lord Cornwallis by more than two to one. However, the British take the field but with such heavy losses that, in retrospect, Greene could claim a strategic success.



 Hobkirk’s Hill (25 April 1781) Nathanial Greene’s Marylanders fail to stand against a concerted charge from Lord Rawdon’s smaller but better disciplined army.

name.value: The War Game: World War II
The War Game: World War Two

item.description: Fans often call it "Axis and Allies on Steroids". The rules and mechanics are similar enough to Axis and Allies, but there are a few differences and additions. The game, like Axis and Allies, covers the entire war from a strategic level with areas corresponding mostly to countries, with larger countries broken down. The map is a gargantuan 4' x 8' with eight major powers dividing up the non-neutral world (Germany, Italy, Japan, Russia, UK, USA, China, and France)

item.description:
It is a common form of checkers widely played in the Middle-East, where it is known as Dama.

Played on an 8×8 board, it differentiates with most other games of the Checkers Family because pieces move straight forward or sideways, not diagonally. When a piece reaches the last row it promotes to a flying king (Dama) which moves like the rook in Chess.

item.description: A solo game that enables players to play a complete Test Match in around two hours. You can add individual stats for players, but it adds around 25% to the time to play. A quick, easy and very flexible and exciting game. Perfect for cricket fans who want to play entire series without it becoming a life's work.

This game is from 1900 and was published by the J. Ottmann Litho Company of New York.

The directions say that Commerce is "the most amusing game on the market"

The game is comprised of a deck of cards with 8 suits
 (Pork, Sugar, Cotton, Corn, Coffee, Oats, Flour and Butter) of 6 cards in each suit, making 48 cards in all.

After shuffling the cards, deal each player 6 cards. Each player sorts the cards that they have and then decides which suit they will try to corner.

The object of the game is to obtain all of the cards of one suit by trading with other players.

To play you take from your hand a card or cards of similar suite and holding them up call "Trade 2 or trade 3. All players do that at the same time so there is lots of yelling going on. Sorta like what happens on the New York Stock Exchange. People make trades of cards. So you could trade 2 with someone else then find that the 2 that you receive match a card or two that you already have in your hand and now you might try and trade 3 for 3. When the first player succeeds in getting all of the cards in a suit the player calls "corner" shows the cards to everyone else. First player to get 3 corners wins!

The game is played on a hexagon board composed of 6 blue triangle fields known as Playing Fields. The Playing Fields are divided by rows of red playing spots running toward the center of the board known as Alleys. These Alleys may be traveled from one end to another in a single move if desired. In each game there are 30 shells divided into groups of 5, each group has a different color. There are also 6 counters numbered 5,10,15,20,25 and 50. At the beginning each player draws a counter, looks at it and then places it beneath one of his shells so that no opponent knows under which shell the counter is. . The object of the game is to move a shell into the SHELL OUT area of an opponent. You may attempt to capture a shell of your opponent. If you are next to a opponents shell you simply jump on it. Most shells have nothing under them and simply result in your losing your shell. If you find the shell with the scoring marker under it you score it. The hand is over when someone moves a loaded shell unto the opponents SHELL OUT area.
Issue game of Command Magazine Japan #72, 20 Dec 2006, along with SS: Third Reich.

Issue game of Simulator #33, 25 April 1991.

Republished as an issue game of Command Magazine Japan #72, 20 Dec 2006, along with First World War.

"SS" means "Sugoroku-Simulation".

A multi-player game in which players play German generals fighting for the honor to be the first to reach Moscow.

From the rules: Blue is from the series Factor-5 and is the first jigsaw in which you can compete against other players. You must quickly find suitable pieces to make the jigsaw and then swap the pieces which are the wrong color - you will be surprised by how many possibilities there are.

The game consists of 5 nearly identical jigsaw puzzles of 48 pieces each. There are multiple objects in the picture on the puzzle which are different on each board. All the pieces are then mixed together. Players race to complete the puzzle gaining points for first, second etc. In the second part of the game, players swap pieces to correct errors subtracting incorrect pieces from your score.

Spanish ship-of-the-line game heavily based on Wooden Ships & Iron Men, but set as miniatures rules.

The period covers the Revolutionary and Napoleonic wars at sea and the rules have a complete list of ships available for play of different nations: Spain, Great Britain, France, Portugal, the Ottoman Empire, Russia, Sweden, Holland...

Also includes turns and fire templates for cut and use with the ships.

Home Page (Spanish): http://www.plomoysalitre.com

item.description:
Fortaleses (Fortress) is a push-your-luck dice game, for 2-5 players.

The players try to build the strongest fortress, using dice towers, and they can, also, attack the fortress of the rest of players.

This game wins the 5th Creation Game Contest in the Fira JocJoc in Tona, Catalonia, Spain in 2006.

Rat Race is a card game that is played as fast as possible, all players playing cards simultaneously. Each player has a cheese card in a different maze material (stone, brick, wood, and metal). The cheese card is at the bottom of each player's deck. The rest of the cards are parts of a labyrinth made of the four materials. Players flip over their cards and connect to the existing maze, placing their cards wherever possible. The first player to connect his or her cheese card to the maze wins.

item.description:
In this re-themed edition of Ausgerechnet Buxtehude, we are now trying to learn the geographical locations of cities and sights of Switzerland. In the swiss edition, there also cards with mountains.

Players place cards on the table according to their relative location. Other players may doubt the accuracy of the placement you made. Should the accusations turn out to be true, you would have to give out a scoring marker. The player with the most scoring markers in the end wins.

The game includes 200 location cards with longitude, latitude, and other information about locations.
As there are four languages spoken in Switzerland the rules are supplied also in those four languages (German, French, Italian and Rhaeto-Romanic)

item.description:
Swedish children´s game themed on the Koala Brothers. Players are flying around trying to be the first to visit all their friends. Each player is given 4 tiles, each picturing one of the 9 friends. Up to 9 tiles per player can be used `for a more complex game´. Players roll the die and move on the square grid on the board, visiting squares where the friends are. Friends must be visited in the same order as the tiles in front of the player. Squares are either empty or have a picture of a friend or an airplane. The airplane shows the direction that players must leave that square. First player to visit all 4 (or more) friends is the winner.

Contents:
Game board
4 pawns
36 picture tiles
Die

5 years and up

Note: This game is not identical to Die Koala BrÃ¼der: Auf Geht's Nach Haus!(GameID: 21833).

item.description: The object of the game is to get 20 or more Moose Spotting points. All players should have the same number of turns before one is declared the champion Moose Spotter.

Swedish children´s game themed on the TV-series Höjdarna. Roll the colored die and move towards the air balloon in the middle of the board. If you get the right cards you can move there quicker. Suddenly the balloon will take off. Will you be on board?

Swedish children´s game. The 36 wooden tiles each show either the front or the back of a lamb on a colored background, so that the tiles match up into 18 lambs with a red background, a green background etc. Players roll the die and turn up tiles. When two tiles match the player may take that lamb. There are black lambs to mess things up. If the die shows the picture of a lamb, the first player to sound like a lamb may take one lamb from any player. The player with the most lambs is the winner.

Contents:

36 wooden tiles
Die
Rules

Swedish card game featuring Alfons and friends from the books and short films by Gunilla Bergström. 58 cards are dealt equally among the players. One card is placed face-up on the table. The starting player turns up the top card from his deck. If it is the same character as the open card, or if the balloons on the cards are the same color, the player plays the card on a common pile and continues turning his cards. When the cards don´t match the player discards his card and the next player turns up his top card. If a player turns up a card that is both the same character and the same balloon color as the open card, he may put all his discards on the pile. Players may have to turn their discard pile into a new draw deck. The first player to run out of cards is the winner.

No decisions to make at all, but an easy game for small kids.

item.description: Early 20th century roll and move Bicycle race game. The colorful board represents a 100 mile race. Published in Australia.

A very different type of roll and move game.

The board has been replaced by two rolled paper bands in plastic boxes. The Bikes with riders sit on top.

Dice are rolled to determine how far your rider goes, but instead of moving the rider across a board, you simply turn the rollers to advance the roll (which serves as the tracks).

Nitty Gritty: The Star Game

If you are an eager beaver, here's your chance to get even steven with any funny bunny, providing you don't get into double trouble in which case any hanky panky could become hairy scary. So don't dilly dally, but get down to the nitty gritty so you can razzle dazzle without phoney baloney - and that, silly Billy, is super duper. Does this sound like mumbo jumbo? (From the box)

The game consists of 154 printed cards which, when properly matched with each other, make 77 pairs. Pair examples are: Mellow Yellow / Roly Poly / Plain Jane / Hebbie Jebbies...etc.

Each of the 154 cards has one word and from one to three stars printed on the face of the card. The number of stars indicates the value of the card.

The purpose of the game is to win as many matched pairs of cards as possible. When the stockpile of cards is gone, the player with the greatest number of stars is the winner.

item.description:
From publisher's website:

After the death of the beloved Royal Mage of the kingdom, the king of the land set out a challenge to find his replacement. Wizards from far and wide came to vie for the position. As the challenge was set forth a few of the smarter and sneakier ones thought of a good way to get a leg up. They made their way into the secret dungeon of the former Royal Mage and decided to loot it for what they needed to win... But only one can win, so the battle for the loot began.

Lootin' Wizards is a fun group card/board game where you race around the randomly placed dungeon, trying to get more loot than your opponents. Make spells to battle each other, using the ingenious three card spell system (for thousands of possible creations). Screw up their spells with troublesome Side Effects. Foil them with entertaining Trap cards. Use helpful Items to aid your quest to grab all the Loot you can.

item.description:
From Khyber Pass Games website
 George Armstrong Custer and The Battle of the Little Bighorn have long overshadowed the Battle of the Rosebud. Preceding the Little Bighorn by a week, the outcome of this battle directly influenced what happened to Custer and the 7th US Cavalry.
 General George Crook was given command of the Southern column of the Bighorn Campaign. With Gibbon's column coming in from the West and the Terry/Custer column from the Northeast, the campaign's objective was to trap the Sioux and Northern Cheyenne and forcibly return them back to their reservation.
 Tactically the battle was inconclusive. Casualties on both sides were relatively low, and in the end Crook held the field. But strategically the Rosebud fight was a great victory for the Sioux and Cheyenne. Crook expended a huge amount of ammunition; most soldiers were down to 10 rounds or fewer each. Many horses were killed, injured, or worn out. Because of these reasons Crook decided to withdraw his command back to his base camp, effectively taking his column out of the campaign.
 Had Crook been able to continue operations he could have linked up with Custer's column, adding his infantry and cavalry to the 7th Cavalry. Custer's last stand would have, in all probability, never have occurred.
 Game scale:
Each combat unit represents:
 - one US Cavalry company
 - approximately 100 Indians
 - individual leader
Each hex equals 1/4 mile across.
Each game turn represents 20 minutes.

This game will be re-released by Legion Wargames as a boxed game with die-cut EasyPunch counters. Also being re-released is Volume I in the series Battle of the Little Bighorn.

This game is part of a series: The Battle of Rosebud Creek, The Battle of the Little Bighorn, and The Battle of Adobe Walls.

link.value: Indian Wars of the American West

item.description:
The standalone game Ladybohn: Manche mögen's heiss! ("Some like it hot!") is a marriage of the Bohnanza base game and the Ladybohn expansion that first appeared in 2002 — but now with babies added to the mix!

This game features 110 cards, with a reworked distribution of the basic beans from Bohnanza. For example, Ladybohn: Manche mögen's heiss! still has six "Gartenbohnen", but now four of the cards are male, one is female, and one is a baby; there are 21 "Blauen Bohnen", 11 of which are male, with five females and five babies. As with the original Ladybohn expansion, the female beans have better beanometers than the male beans, so if you harvest a field with a lady on top, you'll likely receive more coins. The new babies have no beanometer, so harvesting a field topped by a baby is worthless; when a baby is planted in a field, however, a female bean in the field can move two cards toward the top of the stack, which means the babies can bring the superior females where they are needed most.

In English, Ladybohn: Manche mögen's heiss! is included in the standalone expansion Bohnanza: Ladies & Gangsters.

item.description:
It is the national form of checkers in Italy, where it is called Dama. 
Played on an 8×8 board (rotate 90 degree with respect to Checkers, it differentiates with most other games of the Checkers Family because men can't jump kings. Another peculiarity are the jump rules, which define with more cases which move is compulsory in case of multiple possible jumps.

Men move and capture only diagonally forward. Kings move and capture diagonally forwards and backwards but don't fly.

This game can be played online at Ludoteka

item.description: Conga is a two-dimensional game which combines characteristics of Kalah games with four in a row. One players uses 10 black seeds, the other 10 white seeds. Players start with their cache of seeds in opposite corners of the board. The contents of a pit are distributed into the succeeding pits in a particular manner not unlike the "sowing" that happens in Mancala games. The object of the game is to form a row of four occupied holes (the colors of the seeds don't matter), diagonally or orthogonally. In addition, you win if your opponent can't move.

Play doctor and be the first to make the teddy bear better. Move your character around the board, placing bandages on boo-boos as you go. Watch out for gauzy shortcuts. When you reach the lollipop, flip it over and put it on the bears mouth. You made him smile and you win.

Combination Board, 4 Games (boxed):
Manufactured by Wilder Mfg. Co., St. Louis, MO., U.S.A., around 1920, before they carved up Germany and Austria-Hungary and created Poland, etc., because the map matches 1918 Europe.
This set of 4 games (designed for 2 to 4 players) in one box includes two folding game boards with a game on each side. The four games are: 1. Indian Home Game (looks and plays like Parcheesi); 2. Game Hunt (move around the board scoring points for shooting critters -- Rabbit = 1, Lion = 12); 3. Army and Navy (move around a map of WWI Europe, scoring points for capturing enemy officers and weapons -- Zeppelin = 1, Flag and General = 10); 4. Auto Race (race around a track, avoid obstacles, cross finish line 1st).

Contents: Two 12" x 12" mounted game boards with a different game on each side, 16 1/2-inch round wooden playing pieces (4 red, 4 yellow, 4 green, 4 blue), and 1D6 (wooden) in a 6.5" x 14" x 1.5" flat box. The rules for 3 games are inside the lid; the Auto Race game has the rules right on the board.

A game in Kärnan´s line of wooden games for children. This is an educational game to help children learn to read and write. The game features 77 wooden tiles with letters and 8 double-sided boards with pictures and some letters. Players connect tiles to make the words matching the picture on each line.

5 years and up.

item.description:
A member of the Checkers Family common in The Netherlands, France and Russia.

International Checkers is played just like American Checkers or British draughts, with the exception that it is played on a 10x10-square checker board with twenty pieces per player. This game is played mostly in European countries like France, The Netherlands, Russia, Poland and Belgium and in African nations like Congo, Senegal and Ivory Coast. However, there are countries outside these two continents that boast of good players like in the United States, Italy, Israel and Brazil.

Rules of the Game: This game is played on a 10 x 10, or 100 squares checker board where the double corner is on the right of each player.

The Moves of the Men: Checkers pieces can move forward on each empty square to the left or to the right. When these pieces reach the last line on the opponent's side they become kings.

The Moves of the King: Kinged pieces can move across multiple squares on the two diagonals that cross their position for so long as these squares are open, in a rule known as the "flying kings."

Captures: In International checkers, maximum captures are obligatory, which means that if a player has more than one path to jump to capture his opponent's pieces, he must take that path that will effect the most capture of his opponent's pieces. If a piece lands on the king row during a jump, it must continue jumping backward for as long as there is a jump opportunity. That particular piece cannot be kinged unless it finishes the move and stops on king row.

Captures by the Men: Men can effect capture by moving forward or backward and jumping over a single piece of the opponent provided that the said piece is adjacent to it and the following square is empty. If the man can jump again from the arrival square to effect another capture, then it must do so.

Captures by a King: A kinged piece can capture an opponent's piece if it is on the same diagonal where it is positioned provided that the squares between them are empty and that the square beyond the piece to be captured is also empty. The king can stop on any square within the same diagonal line and if another capture can be effected from any of these squares, then it must continue to do so.

The Winning Player: The player who cannot move any of his pieces loses the game.

Conditions for a Draw:

 By mutual agreement of the players.
 Both players have played five moves, after a position arises of one king against two pieces, which includes a king.
 Both players have played sixteen moves, after a position arises of one king against three pieces, which includes a king.
 Both players have moved twenty five moves solely with kings and not a single piece was captured.
 For the third time the same position arises with the same player at move.




Information from checkershistory.com

Online Play 

 Boardspace.net (real time play against humans, or play against the computer)
 SkillGamesBoard (cross-platform, real-time, human opponents or bots, turn-based for registered users)

item.description: Rumble Robots was a children's collectible card game sold in starter decks and booster packs circa 2001. The premise is based around warring factions of sci-fi robots. There are two sides: a blue team of good guys, and a red team of bad guys, each lead by a robot king. The blue king is King El Smasho and the red king is King Slugnut. The cards themselves are called Power Cards and contain bar codes for interaction with Rumble Robots toys. Each card has a "power level" from 1-5 which corresponds to both its rarity and relative usefulness in the game. In addition, there are "platinum" cards, more powerful than level 5 cards. One expansion set was released, "Rumble Robots: Invasion", which focused on the two king characters as well as adding a further rarity level called "superpower" cards.
All players must hold hands to make Tommy the telephone talk. Tommy tells you what picture to find by making silly sounds. When Tommy says Time's Up, the person with the most discs wins.

The Snoopy Card Game board consists of eight popular Peanuts characters--Charlie Brown, Sally, Lucy, Schroeder, Peppermint Patty, Woodstock, Franklin and Linus. Players try to march along the paw-print path to the finish by matching cards from their hands with the characters on the board. By collecting "scoring bowls" players move one, two, three or four spaces at a time. Each round ends with players drawing a card from the player to their right. Amongst the various character cards are eight "Snoopy Ha-Ha" cards which serve as dead spots in your hand since none of them can match the characters on the board. First player to reach the finish is the winner.
